awd_titl_txt: Conference: FASEB Science Research Conference on Mobile DNA: 25 Years of Discussion and Research, June 23-29, 2019, Palm Springs, CA
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support attendance by graduate students and postdoctoral researchers at the FASEB Science Research Conference on Mobile DNA: 25 Years of Discussion and Research to be held June 23-29, 2019 in Palm Springs, CA.  This meeting is designed to bring together scientists from around the world to present and discuss new research on diverse topics that promise to reveal insights into the function of mobile elements, also known as transposable elements.  Compared to previous meetings, which had a focus on mammalian mobile elements, this meeting will include presentations on organisms from many branches of the Tree of Life.  The meeting format will feature keynote lectures from leaders in the field, as well as a combination of talks and posters to promote scientific exchange in both formal and informal settings.   Early-career participants will benefit from engagement as speakers and poster presenters.  A special session in memory of Barbara McClintock will recognize the contribution of women to this field.   

The scientific focus of the meeting will be on topics that were chosen to highlight the importance of mobile elements in multiple biological functions.  Sessions will highlight: comparative genomics of transposable elements, mobile DNA defense and regulation, mobile DNA modulation of epigenetic and gene regulation, mechanisms of mobilization, mobile DNA and the environment, and population genomics of mobile DNA. The meeting will provide an excellent venue for graduate student and postdoctoral participants, including those from underrepresented groups, to share their research with researchers from the U.S. and abroad and to receive feedback on their work from experts in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

The “Mobile DNA 2019: 25 Years of Discussion and Research” conference was held in Palm Springs, CA, June 23–28, 2019, at the Omni Rancho Las Palmas Resort and Hotel. The conference brought together 139 scientists, students, and postdoctoral fellows from the US and numerous other countries, including France, Germany, Spain, the United Arab Emirates, England, Sweden, Scotland, and Canada. These researchers study all aspects of transposable element (TE) biology in a broad range of species and topics, ranging from direct impacts on genome structure to regulatory innovations, to the roles that mobile DNAs play in human health.  There were 2 keynote speakers, 32 invited talks, and 69 poster presentations. Attendance was diverse with females constituting 42% of attendees and 45% of all invited and selected speakers. Early career scientists (defined as faculty with <10 years of experience, postdoctoral associates, and graduate students) were also well-represented, comprising 71% of attendees in approximately equal proportions.

The objective of the Mobile DNA Conference was to strengthen an emerging new area of research by bringing together a diverse group of investigators with common interests in mobile DNA and to discuss recent advances in how transposable elements have impacted and continue to influence the function of genomes. Compared to earlier editions of the Mobile DNA Conference, our aims with the 2019 meeting were: (i) to broaden its scope towards a much larger diversity of living organisms, and (ii) to substantially strengthen the evolutionary component of the meeting.

The two keynote speakers were Prescott Deininger (Tulane University) and Mark Batzer (Louisiana State University). The choice of these two speakers was not just fortuitous. They, along with Carl Schmid, were organizers of that first meeting that was dedicated solely to TE biology and held at Lake Tahoe in 1994. They provided valuable historical perspectives for the audience, along with remarking on some of their own recent work.  This set the stage for some very exciting interactions and collaborative efforts.

The conference consisted of 12 sessions typically with 3-4 long talks and 3-4 short talks. Topics in each session ranged from two memorial sessions for the founder of the field (highlighting female contributions) and a pioneer in comparative analyses to specific topics related to TE regulation and evolution. Highlights included Dr. Josefa Gonzalez (CSIC-UPF) who presented on the role of TEs in adaptation using Drosophila melanogaster as a model. Other significant contributions came from Edward Chuong (University of Colorado, Boulder) who presented intriguing research demonstrating that TEs are an important source of regulatory elements for genes with innate immunity functions across several mammal lineages and Marla Tharp, a postdoctoral fellow from Alex Bortvin’s lab (Carnegie Institute for Science), who concluded her session by presenting promising approaches to maximizing the ovarian reserve in mice.

In addition to the standard sessions, we hosted two career development sessions and a Meet-the-Experts session. The two career development sessions were focused on postdoctoral researchers and graduate students because of their differing needs. Both were well attended with over 20 seats filled in each. The Meet-the-Experts session took the form of a panel discussion. Comments from surveys tell us that these sessions were considered valuable and should be expanded in the next iteration of the meeting.

The Business Meeting was held Thursday afternoon, June 27.  The attendees expressed strong support for the next conference to be held in 2021.  There was significant discussion regarding the venue, talk formats but overall, the attendees were very pleased with the scope and presentations at the conference.  Discussion about future venues focused, not surprisingly, on the heat and that our group typically prefers the mountains. Big Sky and Snowmass were suggested as future venues. The suggestion was also made to shorten talk lengths to allow for more question time. The group also requested that the next conference be held farther east to encourage more Europeans to attend.

Modified by: David A Ray
